Even within the same disease system, the ideal model design depends on the specifics of the questions asked. Here, we highlight a series of models focused on one of the defining infectious agents of our era: HIV. The virus has challenged science, medicine and public health at every scale, from its deft immune evasion to its death toll of more than 35 million over the last four decades
9 . We describe how clinical needs, research questions and data availability have shaped the design of HIV models across these scales. Unless otherwise indicated, the term ‘HIV’ is inclusive of both HIV-1 and HIV-2.
